Mixed-metal MOFs as efficient catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of furfural, levulinic acid and other carbonyl compounds Punitharaj Vasanthakumar Methodology Conceptualization Investigation Writing – original draft a Duraisamy Senthil Raja Formal analysis b Dharmalingam Sindhuja Visualization Investigation Visualization Software a Srividya Swaminathan Software Validation a Ramasamy Karvembu Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli 620015, India Department of Chemistry National Institute of Technology Tiruchirappalli 620015 India aDepartment of Chemistry, National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli 620015, India b Department of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 30013, Taiwan Department of Chemical Engineering National Tsing Hua University Hsinchu 30013 Taiwan bDepartment of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 30013, Taiwan ⁎ Corresponding author. Crystalline, porous Fe-Ni mixed-metal metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni), were synthesized and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, atomic absorption spectrophotometry (AAS) and nitrogen physisorption measurements. The MOFs were then employed as catalysts for transfer hydrogenation (TH) of biomass derivatives such as furfural and levulinic acid, and various other carbonyl compounds using 2-propanol as a sacrificial hydrogen donor. These heterogeneous catalysts are deemed to be environmentally benign, efficient and recyclable. NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) showcased good catalytic activity with low catalyst loading in short reaction time. The catalysts were recovered and reused several times without significant degradation in catalytic activity. A mechanism for the TH reaction was also proposed. As far as we are aware, this is the first report on the synthesis of furfuryl alcohol and γ-valerolactone (GVL) via TH reaction in just 60 min using a MOF catalyst. Graphical abstract MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) MOF was used as an efficient catalyst for the transfer hydrogenation of levulinic acid, furfural and various carbonyl compounds. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mixed metal MOFs Transfer hydrogenation Furfural Levulinic acid γ-Valerolactone 1.Introduction MOFs are regarded as one of the most promising materials since they have various applications such as gas adsorption, water and air purification, energy storage and catalysis [1–3]. MOFs possess accessible metal nodes which function as the active sites for catalysis. Their properties such as pore size, pore volume and acidity can be tuned, which makes them as preferred materials in catalysis [4,5]. Most of the MOFs reported so far are synthesized by using a metal salt and an organic linker; in some cases, a mixture of organic linkers has also been used, e.g., nMLM [6], PCN-137 [7], PCN-138 [7]and MLM-3 [8]. MOFs that have been synthesized using a mixture of organic linkers possess unique physical and chemical properties (uniform pore structures, atomic-level structural uniformity, tenable porosity, and flexibility in network topology, geometry, dimension, and chemical functionality). Researchers have made a lot of attempts to synthesize mixed-metal MOFs. Synthesizing these kinds of MOFs was often considered to be an arduous task until the first report of mixed-metal MOFs in 2011 by Mahata et al. [9]. Even now, only a few mixed-metal MOFs have been successfully prepared, and among them, only a few of them have been used as catalysts for organic conversions [10,11]. A mixed-metal catalyst differs in chemical and physical properties from a single metal catalyst. Recently, heterogeneous catalysis is directed towards mixed-metal catalysts since they have the capacity for enhanced action and selectivity along with improved stability relative to their single metallic equivalents [12]. In addition to exposing the combination of properties associated with the presence of two different metals, because of the synergic effect between them, new and distinctive properties are often produced by the mixed-metal catalysts [11,13]. Effective preparation of mixed-metal MOFs can result in fine tuning of the properties of MOFs. Transition metal MOFs employ connectors with free reactive functional groups with which the other metal can be coordinated before or during the reaction. It has been stated that the introduction of second metal does not alter the structure of parent framework [14,15]. Vuong et al. reported a new logical method for the synthesis of mixed metal MIL-88B MOFs based on a neutral mixed-metal cluster Fe2Ni(μ3-O) [16]. Compared to single metal MIL-88B(Fe3), mixed metal MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) is more porous in nature. Unlike the conventional negatively charged single metal clusters, the use of neutral mixed metal clusters as nodes in the system reduces the need for compensating anions inside the MIL-88B framework [9]. This causes the porosity of mixed metal MIL-88B to be three times greater than that of single metal analogue [17]. One of the essential processes of organic chemistry is the hydrogenation of organic molecules. Until the last decade, the most preferred way of hydrogenation is using highly reactive acids, precious metal catalysts and solvents, which cause health and environmental hazards. Researchers worldwide have developed an alternative way of hydrogenation, i.e., TH [18,19]. In general, TH is carried out using various hydrogen sources such as alcohol, hydrazine, formic acid etc. Irrespective of the method or source of hydrogen, catalysts play a significant role in facilitating the process. New approaches to improve the selectivity of hydrogenation are in demand due to their crucial industrial applications [20]. TH method is a convenient and effective way to obtain hydrogenated compounds by transferring hydrogen from a non-hydrogen source to substrates [21]. TH reactions are classified into various types such as thermal, base-catalyzed, late transition metal-catalyzed, non-catalytic, organocatalytic etc. Catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) is a powerful process and is now directed towards chemoselectivity of a wide variety of substrates with low catalyst loading. It uses eco-friendly earth-rich transition metals such as Fe, Ni, Co, Mn etc. as catalysts. CTH can be employed to convert biomass derived compounds such as levulinic acid (LA) [22], furfural [23]and o-vanillin [24] into their corresponding hydrogenated products of economic and environmental importance. Researchers have been searching for renewable resources following our current economic and sustainable situation [25]. Cheap and green biomass is a promising raw material to produce chemicals and fuels because of its abundance [26]. For example, cellulose is an essential biomass feedstock that can be successfully converted into valuable chemicals such as LA, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), 1,4-pentanediol, GVL etc. Among them, GVL is known to be a versatile building block that could be used as a fuel additive for transportation, and precursor for the manufacture of monomers and value-added chemicals such as organic solvents, bio-oxygenates and biofuels [23]. Because of its outstanding physicochemical properties including low melting and boiling points, and ready miscibility with water without creating an azeotropic mixture, it proved to be an excellent green solvent for biomass processing. Previously, different catalysts have been used to convert LA to GVL, like platinum oxide, zirconium-based zeolites, Raney Ni, mixed-metal oxides and noble metal-based catalysts such as Ru, Re, Ir, Pd, Pt etc. [27–29]. Drawbacks of these methods include harsh reaction conditions, and poor recyclability of the catalysts. To overcome these problems, many groups are focussing on the development of catalysts for the synthesis of GVL from LA through CTH reactions which avoid the usage of hydrogen gas and noble metals [30]. The reactions involving alcohols (hydrogen donor) obtained from renewable resources are preferred [31]. Similarly, chemoselective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol has drawn considerable interest due to the relevance of latter in chemical industries, and the low-cost production of furfural from the renewable resources [32,33]. For the manufacture of chemical products like vitamin C, plasticizers, dispersing agents, resins and lubricants, furfuryl alcohol is an essential intermediate [34]. The conversion of furfural is typically done in either gas or liquid phase. Compared to the liquid phase hydrogenation procedure, large amounts of side products and high energy consumption occur while using gas phase method. Mainly Ni, Cu, Co, Pt and Pd-based catalytic hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol in the liquid phase were investigated widely [35]. Cu-Cr-based catalysts have been commonly used in industries. However, the use of Cr, and the bulk use of organic solvents such as THF, octane etc., can cause significant damages to the environment. Recently, water has been used as solvent under mild conditions for converting furfural to furfuryl alcohol [36], and MOF-based catalysts were used successfully for this objective [23]. We have concentrated primarily on the mixed-metal MOF with an appreciable pore size for use as a catalyst for the chemoselective CTH reactions. This catalyst constitutes a step forward in creating an efficient process for biomass conversions under mild reaction conditions. Our previous work demonstrated that MIL-88B(Fe3) catalyst exhibits good selectivity for the CTH of various carbonyl compounds and biomass derivatives. But the sincere drawback of work was the long reaction time of 10 h [37]. We report here the catalytic activity of mixed-metal MOF MIL-88B(Fe2Ni), which is ten times higher than that of the single metal MOF MIL-88B(Fe3). 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Levulinic acid (99%), acetophenone and substituted acetophenones, benzaldehyde and substituted benzaldehydes, 2-propanol (99%), FeCl3⋅6H2O (98%), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (98%), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 98%), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (99%) and N,N-dimethylformamide (99.8%) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Formic acid (99%) and terephthalic acid (99%) were purchased from Alfa-Aesar. All the chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Physical methods FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet iS5 FT-IR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) using iD3 ATR mode in the range of 4000–550 cm−1. PXRD patterns were recorded on a PanAlytical B.V.Empyrean diffractometer using CuKα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) from 5 to 50° 2θ range at the scan rate of 1°/min. The specific surface area was determined from N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at liquid N2 temperature using a Belsorp Max system with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. SEM analysis was performed on a Zeiss EVO-15 instrument. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis was carried out on a Shimadzu GC-MS QP 2010 ultra-instrument equipped with ZB-5 M plus Phenomenex column of 30 m length and 0.25 mm inner diameter, and the relative conversion and selectivity were found by calculating the area under the peak. Mass was matched with NIST or Wiley library; all the GC-MS results have similar retention indexes irrespective of the analysis time. Mass was analyzed by scan mode (from m/z 45 to 750). 2.3 Synthesis of MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and its amine-functionalized analogue MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) were synthesized according to the reported procedure [38]. 3 mmol of FeCl3⋅6H2O (810.90 mg), 1.5 mmol of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (274.05 mg) and 4.5 mmol of terephthalic acid (747 mg) or 2-amino terephthalic acid (816.75 mg) were dissolved in 100 mL of DMF. To the clear solution, 1.5 mmol of CH3COOH (1.5 mL) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 10 min and refluxed at 125 °C for 5 h (Scheme 1 ). The resulting brown precipitate was collected, washed with DMF, ethanol and water, and dried under vacuum. The solid was ground into a fine powder and used as such for characterization and catalysis. 2.4 Catalysis In a typical procedure, a certain amount of catalyst, reactant and solvent were added to a round bottom flask (10 mL). Subsequently, the reaction temperature was fixed according to the experiment (25, 40, 60, 80, 90 or 100 °C), and one equivalent of base was used. The reaction begins after the addition of base. Aliquots of the reaction mixture at different times were diluted with solvent and subjected to GC-MS analyses. At the end of reaction, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation at 40,000 rpm for 15 min and then the product was extracted with ethyl acetate. 2.5 Hot filtration test and AAS analysis A hot filtration test was performed with MIL-88B(Fe2Ni). In a typical reaction, MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) (2 mg, 0.0027 mmol), 2-propanol (3 mL, 39.43 mmol), acetophenone (117 µL, 1 mmol) and NaOH (40 mg, 1 mmol) were taken in a round bottom flask, and the reaction proceeded for 30 min at 90 °C. The reaction mixture was then centrifuged, and the catalyst was separated off. The filtrate was divided into two parts. One part was refluxed at the identical conditions as the former for another 40 min, and the products were extracted with ethyl acetate and analyzed by GC-MS. The other part was used for GC–MS and AAS analyses. GC-MS analysis gave conversion at 30 min. From AAS analysis, the amount of metal leached was found. 2.6 Mercury drop test MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) (2 mg, 0.0027 mmol), 2-propanol (3 mL, 39.43 mmol), acetophenone (117 μL, 1 mmol), NaOH (40 mg, 1 mmol) and two drops of Hg were placed in a 10 mL round bottom flask fitted with a reflux condenser at 90 °C for 60 min. The product was extracted and subjected to GC-MS analysis. 2.7 Reuse of the catalysts Both the catalysts were reused for 5 cycles. The recycling of catalysts was performed by following a specific process as stated. Firstly, after the reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The supernatant was processed and subjected to GC-MS analysis. The catalyst was washed twice with 3 mL of DMF, ethanol, water, and acetone, dried and activated at 150 °C for 6 h in vacuum and reused. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the MIL-88B catalysts PXRD patterns of the prepared MOFs matched well with the calculated models [23]. Both the catalysts showed signature peaks around 9 and 10°, which corresponded to 110 and 101 planes, respectively (Figs. 1a and S1a). N2 adsorption measurements were carried out for MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) catalysts, and their specific surface area was found to be 407 and 324 m2g−1, respectively (Figs. 1b and S1b). The shape of hysteresis loop was characteristic of type IV adsorption isotherm (multilayer adsorption) [25], and the catalyst possessed uniform pores. With SEM analysis, the surface morphology was found to be spindle shaped [38] (Figs. 2 and S2). A sharp peak seen around 750 cm-1 in their FT-IR spectra indicated the presence of metal-oxygen bonds (Fe-O/Ni-O). N-H stretching frequency was observed at 3376 cm−1, and N-H bending frequency was found around 1250 cm−1 in the spectrum of NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) [39,40]. 3.2 CTH effected by the mixed-metal MIL-88B catalysts 3.2.1 CTH of acetophenone - optimization of reaction parameters CTH of acetophenone was used as a model reaction to optimize the parameters such as temperature, time, the quantity of base and the amount of solvent required. The effect of temperature on CTH was studied in the temperature range of 25–140 °C (Figure S3). The yield of 1-phenylethanol at 25 °C was minimal (22%). An increase in temperature to 40 and 60 °C increased the yield proportionally to 50 and 73%, respectively. The complete conversion was obtained at 90 °C. Further increase in temperature to 100, 120 and 140 °C did not alter the yield of product. The ideal time for the CTH was obtained by keeping all other parameters constant [2 mg of MIL-88B(Fe2Ni), 3 mL of 2-propanol, 1 mmol of acetophenone and the reaction temperature of 90 °C] as shown in Figure S4. Aliquots were taken at a time interval of 10 min and subjected to GC-MS analysis. To our delight, a maximum yield of 97% was obtained within 60 min. Thus, the optimum temperature and time were found to be 90 °C and 60 min, respectively. Similarly, the amount of catalyst required for the effective conversion was optimized with various MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) loading (1-4 mg) (Figure S5). When the catalyst amount was low (1 mg), the conversion was less (43%). Conversion with the increase in the catalyst [MIL-88B(Fe2Ni)] loading (2, 3 and 4 mg) was studied. Complete conversion of acetophenone to 1-phenylethanol was obtained with 2 mg of MIL-88B(Fe2Ni). Further increase in MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) amount (above 4 mg) did not alter the conversion. This confirmed that 2 mg (0.0025 mmol) was the minimum amount of catalyst required for the reaction. Further, the effect of different bases on the CTH of acetophenone was evaluated (Figure S6). Weak bases such as K2CO3 and Et3N were not effective in converting acetophenone, whereas strong bases such as NaOH and KOH showed an excellent conversion (98 and 95%). Thus, the scope of reaction was extended to various substituted carbonyl compounds with NaOH. 3.2.2 CTH of various carbonyl compounds Both the catalysts displayed very good activity towards the conversion of acetophenone and other substituted acetophenones. The effect of substitution was examined with different electron-withdrawing and -donating groups. The substrates with electron-withdrawing group such as phenyl or halogen were converted into their respective alcohols very effectively compared to parent acetophenone (Scheme 2 , 3 a). Benzophenone was converted into diphenyl methanol promptly in 55 min (Scheme 2, 3b). The chlorine or bromine substituted acetophenones were converted into 4‑chloro or4‑bromo-1-phenylethanol, respectively, in 60 min (Scheme 2, 3c and 3d). The substrates containing electron-donating group required a bit longer reaction time relative to those with electron-withdrawing group. Methoxy substituted acetophenone required 80 min for its complete conversion (Scheme 2, 3e). Further, the versatility of the catalysts was explored with various carbonyl substrates. The conversion of benzaldehyde to benzyl alcohol was quicker (45 min) than that of acetophenone and substituted acetophenone derivatives (Scheme 2, 3f). 2-adamantanone was converted entirely into 2-adamantanol, which established compatibility of the catalysts with bicyclic systems (Scheme 2, 3g). Lastly, the aliphatic carbonyl compound (cinnamaldehyde) was also converted into its alcohol (cinnamyl alcohol) with good conversion of 91% (Scheme 2, 3h). The studies proved the usefulness of MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) catalysts for the TH of various carbonyl compounds including aromatic, aliphatic and alicyclic substrates. 3.2.3 CTH of biomass derivatives CTH of biomass derivatives such as furfural and levulinic acid was performed with MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni). Fortunately, excellent conversion (99%) of furfural and levulinic acid to furfuryl alcohol and GVL, respectively, was obtained within 60 min, with excellent selectivity (99%) (Scheme 3, 3i and Scheme 4 , 3j). The TOF values for these conversions were much higher than those exhibited by single metal counterpart MIL-88B(Fe3) (Table 1 ). 3.2.4 Chemoselective reduction of nitro group It was observed that the nitro functional group was preferentially reduced over the carbonyl (C=O) functional group in presence of MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) or NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) catalyst. Both the catalysts exhibited decent selectivity (92%) in the reduction of 3-nitroacetophenone to 3-aminoacetophenone (Scheme 5 , 3k). Interestingly, the position of nitro group has altered the chemoselectivity as the selectivity of reduction of 2-nitroacetophenone was significantly reduced (71%) (Scheme 6 , 3l). 3.2.5 Gram scale synthesis of GVL To understand the catalytic activity of MOFs at higher scale, reaction was performed with 40 mmol of levulinic acid (4.6 g). The quantity of NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and other reagents was increased accordingly. After the reaction, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation, and the crude reaction mixture was passed through a short neutral alumina column, and the product was extracted with an excess of ethyl acetate. A pure product of GVL (3.98 g) was obtained after carefully evaporating the solvent. The activity and selectivity remained the same even in the gram scale; this disclosed the compatibility of NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) in the gram scale process. 3.2.6 Effect of NH2 substitution in the organic linker of MIL-88B on the CTH reaction The TOF values obtained for various substrates concluded that the amino group containing MOF displayed better catalytic activity than its unsubstituted counterpart (Fig. 3 ). This might be because of additional basicity provided by the amino group, which in turn stabilize the isopropoxide intermediate produced during the reaction. 3.2.7 Reusability of the mixed-metal MOF NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) was used to test the reusability and stability of mixed-metal MOFs. The catalyst was reused after solvent washing (3 × 5 mL of 2-propanol and acetone) and activation at 150 °C under vacuum for 2 h. Reusability was studied for the conversion of LA to GVL. The catalyst (recycled) exhibited similar activity in all the five cycles to that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 4 ). Though the conversion varied by ±2%, the selectivity remained constant in all the cycles. The crystallinity and stability of the reused catalyst were confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figure S19). All these proved that NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) catalyst possesses a long catalytic life. 3.2.8 Heterogeneous nature of the mixed-metal MOF Hot filtration test results showed that the conversion of LA to GVL did not happen after the removal of catalyst NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) from the reaction mixture, i.e., the mixed-metal MOF indeed functioned as a heterogeneous catalyst (Fig. 5 ). A part of the reaction mixture (after the removal of catalyst) was subjected to AAS analysis, and the leaching of metal ions was found to be 1.55 ppm of Fe and 0.77 ppm of Ni. The trace leaching of metal ions was the reason for the meager increase in the conversion even in the absence of catalyst. Further, ICP-MS analysis was performed for the fresh and recovered catalysts (Table 2 ), which also confirmed the leaching of metal ions from the catalysts. In the case of MIL-88B(Fe2Ni), the leaching of Fe and Ni was found to be 1.7 and 0.3%, respectively while it was 1.7 (Fe) and 0.5% (Ni) in the case of NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) catalyst. Moreover, the conversion (96%) remained unaffected in the presence of mercury drops, which confirmed that free metal ions that leached out were not involved in the catalysis. 3.2.9 Kinetics To understand the CTH reaction of LA over NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni), kinetic studies were performed under three different reaction temperatures. In the present system, 2-propanol was used in excess, and therefore, the kinetics of reaction was assumed to be not affected by the concentration of 2-propanol. Thus, the CTH was considered as a pseudo-first order reaction wherein the rate depends only on the LA concentration. Fig. 6 shows the plot of ln Ct/C0 vs time for the conversion of LA over NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni), where C0 is the initial concentration of LA, and Ct represents the concentration of LA at a particular time. As shown in Fig. 6, the reaction followed pseudo-first order kinetics at all the studied temperatures. Rate constant values were determined to be 0.7024, -1.1324, -1.6326 and -3.0108 min−1 at 313, 333, 353 and 363 K, respectively. The variation of rate constant (k) with temperature is shown in the insert of Fig. 6. Based on the Arrhenius plot, the activation energy (Ea) was calculated and found to be 25.22 kJmol−1. The previously reported activation energy for LA to GVL conversion was 86.45 kJmol−1, which was about 3 times higher than ours [41]. Hence, we conclude that NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) mixed-metal catalyst showed exceptional activity in LA to GVL conversion. 3.2.10 Mechanism The mechanism of CTH of carbonyl compounds using MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) catalyst is illustrated in Fig. 7 . Firstly, the deprotonation of 2-propanol is initiated by the base, leading to an active isopropoxide species which interacts with the metal center (Ni) via C-O (Step 1). The Fe center abstracts the hydride, and isopropoxide is given out as acetone followed by the interaction of the substrate with the catalyst via Fe-H (Step 2). Hydride from the Fe is then transferred to the carbonyl carbon, and proton is abstracted again from the system to form an alcohol product (Step 3). 3.2.11 Superiority of the mixed-metal MIL-88B catalytic system The catalytic efficiency of mixed-metal MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) MOFs towards the conversion of LA to GVL was compared with that of the corresponding single metal MOFs (Table S1). It was evident that the mixed-metal MOFs expressed an excellent catalytic activity [TOF = 250 h−1 for benzaldehyde with NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni)] compared to the single metal MOFs [TOF = 6 h−1 for benzaldehyde with MIL-88B(Fe2Ni)]. The superior activity of the mixed-metal MOFs can be attributed to their higher surface area. The catalytic performance of the MOFs was also compared with the other reported catalysts in the literature, which used 2-propanol as a hydrogen source (Table 3 ). It was obvious that the mixed-metal MOFs exhibited excellent selectivity compared to the reported catalysts. Most of the catalysts required either harsh conditions for the reaction or a tedious process for catalyst preparation. Thus, from the viewpoint of easy preparation of catalysts, their high surface area and short CTH reaction time, MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) MOFs are the best catalysts for the TH of carbonyl compounds including biomass derived substrates. 4 Conclusions Two Fe-Ni MIL-88B MOFs were synthesized and characterized. MOFs exhibited a spindle shaped morphology which was confirmed by SEM analysis. Mixed-metal MOFs presented here displayed 10 times more surface area than single metal MOFsMIL-88B(Fe3). Both the mixed-metal MOFs were successfully applied as catalysts for the CTH of various carbonyl compounds including aromatic, aliphatic, alicyclic and biomass-derived substrates. Also, the catalysts selectively reduced nitro group in the presence of carbonyl moiety. The mixed-metal MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) MOFs exhibited 10-fold higher catalytic activity than single metal MIL-88B(Fe3) MOFs. There are a few reports which highlight the base (NaOH or KOH)-catalyzed TH of carbonyl compounds. These bases are effective only for simple substrates such as acetophenone and benzaldehyde, unlike the present system. Hence, MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) MOFs have many advantages including high surface area, high porosity, excellent activity and very good chemical stability. Also, the TH reaction uses an environmentally benign hydrogen donor/solvent, and it has low activation energy. coredata.dc:description: Crystalline, porous Fe-Ni mixed-metal metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) and NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni), were synthesized and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, atomic absorption spectrophotometry (AAS) and nitrogen physisorption measurements. The MOFs were then employed as catalysts for transfer hydrogenation (TH) of biomass derivatives such as furfural and levulinic acid, and various other carbonyl compounds using 2-propanol as a sacrificial hydrogen donor. These heterogeneous catalysts are deemed to be environmentally benign, efficient and recyclable. NH2-MIL-88B(Fe2Ni) showcased good catalytic activity with low catalyst loading in short reaction time. The catalysts were recovered and reused several times without significant degradation in catalytic activity. A mechanism for the TH reaction was also proposed. As far as we are aware, this is the first report on the synthesis of furfuryl alcohol and γ-valerolactone (GVL) via TH reaction in just 60 min using a MOF catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Mixed-metal MOFs as efficient catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of furfural, levulinic acid and other carbonyl compounds
